awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the principal investigator's research projects within the general framework of definable equivalence relations on Polish spaces, which is a modern focus of descriptive set theory. This theory provides a general framework for understanding the nature of classification of mathematical objects up to some notion of equivalence, and, due to its broad scope, it has natural interactions with many areas of mathematics. A central place in this theory is occupied by countable Borel equivalence relations (CBERs), which arise via actions of countable groups as well as via locally countable graphs. These connections between equivalence relations, group actions, and graphs create an extremely fruitful interplay between descriptive set theory, ergodic theory, measured group theory, and descriptive graph combinatorics. The overarching goal of the reseach is to deepen the understanding of these connections and further the theory of CBERs having major open questions as guiding targets.

The projects can be grouped into four topics. The first concerns closure properties of the class of treeable CBERs, namely, whether abstract quasi-isometries and finite index extensions preserve treeability in the Borel or measurable contexts. Next is the investigation of the quasi-invariant setting aiming to develop a theory of quasi-invariant cost. The third topic is the existence of desirable subgraphs of graphings of a CBER, e.g., the existence of cost-approximating subgraphings or subtreeings, as well as that of maximal hyperfinite free factors. The last part is devoted to the pointwise ergodic theorems, namely, proving new instances and finding new proofs of known ones using a pointwise-combinatorial tiling argument in the style of the PI's recent proof the Birkhoff ergodic theorem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Below, the PI refers to Anush Tserunyan.

The overarching theme of the project is analyzing the extent to which the global structure of a large object of dynamical nature (e.g. a group action) influences its local structure (e.g. individual orbits), and vice versa. The outcomes of the project are grouped into two topics.

1) Pointwise ergodic theorems.


Following the  general method for proving pointwise ergodic theorems uncovered earlier by the PI, she and her PhD student Jenna Zomback prove a new - backward - ergodic theorem for an ergodic probability-measure-preserving (pmp) transformation T. The theorem says that the mean of any integrable function is approximated a.e. by the averages taken over arbitrary trees of possible pasts, i.e. subtrees of the graph of T rooted at a point x and lying behind x in the direction of T^{-1}. Surprisingly, this theorem yields a pointwise ergodic theorem for all pmp actions of free groups of finite rank, where the averages are taken over arbitrary subtrees of the Cayley graph rooted at the identity. This proves a conjecture of Bufetov from 2022. It also strengthens the conclusion of the best known result in this vein due to Bufetov (2000), and generalizes and strengthens theorems of Grigorchuk (1986) and Nevo (1994).

Another significant outcome in this topic is the solo work of the PI that was finalized during the award period. Generalizing an earlier unpublished theorem of Tucker-Drob for pmp graphs, the PI proves that every ergodic Borel graph on a probability space admits an ergodic hyperfinite subgraph. This result yields a pointwise ergodic theorem for all Schreier graphs of quasi-pmp actions of countable groups. The classical kinds of pointwise ergodic theorems are known to fail for pmp actions of nonamenable groups (Tao 2015) and for quasi-pmp actions of even abelian groups (Hochman 2013), so this ergodic theorem for Schreier graphs is the best possible in such generality.

2) Quasi-pmp group actions and graphs.

The project significantly contributed to the theory of quasi-pmp group actions and graphs, which, unlike its pmp counterpart, is much less developed.

The PI's joint work with Robin Tucker-Drob lays the foundation for the systematic study of quasi-pmp equivalence relations. It provides a comprehensive analysis of hyperfinite equivalence relations within a quasi-pmp treeing, with a plethora of standalone results, most notably, a complete characterisation of when quasi-pmp treeings are amenable, in terms of the behavior of the Radon-Nikodym cocycle on the ends of the treeing. In the absence of the theory of cost for quasi-pmp group actions and graphs, this is the first class of graphs for which amenability is now fully understood in the quasi-pmp setting.

Building on this is another work of the PI, joint with her former postdoc Ruiyuan Chen and her PhD student Grigory Terlov. This work gives a complete characterization of when multi-ended quasi-pmp graphs are amenable. In fact, an algorithm is provided for finding in nonamenable such graphs a subforest witnessing nonamenability (according to the PI's work with Tucker-Drob described above). This algorithm also applies in the percolation theory of nonunimodular graphs, providing a suitable analogue for the nonunimodular setting of the Free Minimal Spanning Forest.

Broader impact.

In the duration of the award, the PI has supervised a MSc student and four PhD students, one of whom, Jenna Zomback, graduated in 2022, and the others will be graduating in 2023. Zomback is now a visiting assistant professor at Williams College and will continue next year as a postdoc at the University of Maryland. The PI has also mentored two postdocs at UIUC: Ruiyuan Chen and Pavlos Motakis. Chen received an NSF grant and the CRM-Simons fellowship in 2021, followed by a postdoctoral position at the University of Michigan. Motakis is already a tenure-track assistant professor at York University. Some of the UIUC undergraduates supervised by the PI are now PhD students at schools such as UCLA and University of Washington.

The PI has been involved in the organization of 10 conferences/workshops/long-term programs, 6 of which have already taken place. These include interdisciplinary workshops at the Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach (Oberwolfach), BIRS (Banff), CRM (Montr?al), Fields Institute (Toronto), and CIRM (Luminy), as well as a 6-month-long thematic program in geometric group theory at the CRM.

Together with Marcin Sabok, the PI founded and has been running a Descriptive Dynamics and Combinatorics seminar [https://www.math.mcgill.ca/atserunyan/DDC-Seminar], virtually and in person, providing PhD students and postdocs from various universities a venue for gaining visibility and disseminating their results.

Dissemination of results.

In the duration of the grant, the PI has given 28 invited talks, which include 6 general mathematics colloquia and one plenary conference address. The PI has also taught an invited mini-course at the "C*-dynamics and Set Theory School in Paris 2022" on her program for proving pointwise ergodic theorems.
